For all those confused about why you need 2^256 guesses and not 2^255. Here is an answer from 3Blue1Brown from a reply:

To the point about it really requiring half as many guesses, (i.e. 2^255 not 2^256): This is true for something like hacking a digital signature, where you are methodically going through all possibilities. But if a cryptographic hash function truly behaves like a random function, guessing and checking a nonce with a hash will not look like going through all possible hashes one-by-one, it's more like rolling a die over and over until you hit a 6, in which the expected number of rolls needed is 6, not 3. While running this GigaGalactic supercomputer, many of the guesses will actually collide, so it is not a methodical search through all possible hashes.

However, as you point out, the actual security on SHA256 is indeed lower than 256-bits. It turns out not to quite behave like a nice random function. But this discussion just centered on an idealized cryptographic hash function.

I doubt anybody will ever see this, but I came up with my own analogy to describe how absurdly huge this number really is. FIrst off, I saw in some other random YT video - that humans are pumping out roughly 60 quintillion inputs for the SHA 256 per second. So if humanity continued calculating at this pace, how long would we have to keep computing before we found 2 inputs that equate to the same output?

TLDR: A long fucking time.

Analogy: We have a lot of time to kill, so let's start by imagining that we kill time by walking in a straight line until we reach the moon. Once you reach the moon, turn around and come home. When you get home, (you would have been gone roughly 18 years) buy a powerball ticket. If that ticket wins the jackpot, buy a mega millions ticket. If the mega millions is ALSO a winner, flick a penny into the Grand Canyon.

After flicking the penny into the Grand Canyon, continue on your walk - back and forth from the Earth to the moon and back. Again, when you return to Earth, buy another powerball ticket. The only way you will ever throw a penny into the Grand Canyon, is if both the Powerball AND Mega Millions tickets are winners. As you could imagine, you're going to do this until all 5.45 million cubic yards of the Grand Canyon is completely filled to the brim with pennies. That's a lot of lotto wins!

Of course you haven't even scratched the surface of how much time needs to pass, so we're going to continue on with this pattern - until you have filled the Grand Canyon with pennies 200,000 times over. Eventually I'm assuming you will get bored of filling the Grand Canyon with pennies, so after 200,000 of these fills you can switch to the Pacific ocean. The pacific ocean is a lot bigger than the Grand Canyon, and it would take about twice as long to fill with pennies as it took to fill the Grand Canyon 200,000 times. Woah.

Now that the pacific ocean is filled to the brim with pennies, empty it out and find a nice place on Earth to park a Chevy Malibu. Return to the Grand Canyon - Fill it with pennies 200,000 times. Return to the pacific ocean, and fill that with pennies as well. Keep in mind, each penny represents winning back-to-back lotteries after a round trip from the Earth to the moon and back at a walking pace. Each Chevy Malibu is going to be the equivalent amount of time as: filling the Grand Canyon with pennies 200,000 times as well as the pacific ocean once.

How many Chevy Malibus will we have to stack before we finally have run out of possible calculations? Answer: It's a fucking lot of Chevy Malibus. You're gonna stack those babies on top of each other until they too reach the moon. Then you're going to start a new stack of Chevy Malibus - and that stack too will also reach the moon. And then you're going to do another.
and another
and another
and another
until you have reached roughly 33.7249 Earth-Moon length stacks of Chevy Malibus. Now that you are exhausted, sick of pennies, and a little over 61 quindecillion years old, you can drive the last Chevy Malibu down the giant cosmic escalator of Malibus from roughly 3/4 of the way to the moon back to Earth where you will finally get to rest - and enjoy seeing 2 different inputs that provide the exact same 256 bit output in the SHA 256. I can only imagine what those 2 different inputs look like. I hope you'll share with the rest of us. Is it a picture of a Chevy Malibu and the dimensions of a penny? Is it one of the back-to-back lottery winning numbers? Who knows? You do. Because you did it.

0:20 - Wrong information. When mining a block in bitcoin, you guess not the whole 256 bits, but only 32-bits nonce value, which is 2^32 = ~4bil. guesses.

The problem is not to guess sha256 for mining bitcoin, the problems is that you have to do it quicker than anyone else - otherwise, someone else mines the block. The system leverages the time for someone to mine the block to be as close as possible to 10 minutes in average. You could guess 4bil nonce value within a day on an average computer - but you won't last competition.

And the secondary problem with bitcoin is that you have to perform sha256 of sha256 - double hash, which doubles the amount of performance time.

Typical cryptocurrencies don't really give you 256 bits of security. Let's consider bitcoin:

1) Public keys are hashed with RIPEMD160, so only 160 bits of security protect your private keys from preimage attack
2) secp256k1 of bitcoin indeed is a 256 bit elliptic curve, however due to the fact that square root attacks on discrete logarithm for generic groups exist, this curve only offers you 128 bits of security against cracking your public keys on elliptic curve if they are known to an attacker
3) The SHA256 hash used in the proof of work is indeed a 256 bit hash, however due to the nature of the proof of work system you don't have to guess an exact hash, you only need to obtain a hash that is lower then a threshold derived from previous blocks via consensus rule so security against malicious group of miners is nowhere near a 256 bit level, it's actually pretty bad by cryptographic standards, since the computational power required to defeat good miners and break the system can be achived by accumulation of hardware

The video is great and I'm not at all trying to discredit it, but there's a small error in which it is stated that, on average, it would require 2^256 guesses to find the correct hash. Since 2^256 is actually the total number of possible guesses that any given sha256 can be, the average number of guesses needed per hash would be 2^256/2 = 2^255 due to the random nature of any given guess being correct. This was cool, but I prefer the thermodynamic-limitation explanation in Applied Cryptography by Bruce Schneier:
"One of the consequences of the second law of thermodynamics is that a certain amount of energy is necessary to represent information. To record a single bit by changing the state of a system requires an amount of energy no less than kT, where T is the absolute temperature of the system and k is the Boltzman constant. (Stick with me; the physics lesson is almost over.)

Given that k=1.38⋅10^−16erg/∘Kelvin, and that the ambient temperature of the universe is 3.2∘K, an ideal computer running at 3.2∘K would consume 4.4⋅10^−16 ergs every time it set or cleared a bit. To run a computer any colder than the cosmic background radiation would require extra energy to run a heat pump.

Now, the annual energy output of our sun is about 1.21⋅10^41 ergs. This is enough to power about 2.7⋅10^56 single bit changes on our ideal computer; enough state changes to put a 187-bit counter through all its values. If we built a Dyson sphere around the sun and captured all of its energy for 32 years, without any loss, we could power a computer to count up to 2^192. Of course, it wouldn’t have the energy left over to perform any useful calculations with this counter.

But that’s just one star, and a measly one at that. A typical supernova releases something like 10^51 ergs. (About a hundred times as much energy would be released in the form of neutrinos, but let them go for now.) If all of this energy could be channeled into a single orgy of computation, a 219-bit counter could be cycled through all of its states.

These numbers have nothing to do with the technology of the devices; they are the maximums that thermodynamics will allow. And they strongly imply that brute-force attacks against 256-bit keys will be infeasible until computers are built from something other than matter and occupy something other than space."

Using the Dyson Sphere example, where would the counter be after 64 years, 128 years, 256 years, 512 years, and 1,024 years? At 2^193, 2^194, 2^195, 2^196, and 2^197, respectively. After 1,048,576 years? 2^207. After 1,073,741,824 years? 2^217. After that... the sun becomes a RED GIANT and CONSUMES the Dyson Sphere. That will PROBABLY be less of a concern than its incineration of the Earth. When would the counter reach the halfway mark, giving a 50% chance of correctly guessing the 256-bit key? At 2^255. When would the counter have a "one-in-a-million" chance? At 2^236. It is IMPOSSIBLE to brute-force 256-bit encryption. (QED)

People need to understand that SHA256 is just a hashing algorithm and not a encryption algorithm. With encryption, you need a algorithm to encrypt the data and a algorithm to decrypt the data so it can be read via plaintext. Hashing algorithm's are a 1-way street, meaning it will scramble your message, but you cannot unscramble it and get the original message back. When people are trying to find the right SHA256, what they are really trying to do is just find a copy of 'YOUR' SHA-256 that the computer accepts as its key. This is good for hiding your private key values, as the number of guesses is so astronomical, that even modern day computers can't keep up. SHA-256 is good for providing Integrity, making sure data itself has not changed, however please do not mistake it for encrypting your data as it does not do this. So when you think of security, you can think of SHA-256 as a good tool for making sure data has not be changed (providing integrity), but not providing security to the level that encryption can offer. SHA-256 is used for many encryption services, masking the key to encrypt and decrypt,  through the hashing algorithm itself.

The problem with these kinds of videos is they don't really describe a realistic scenario. Most importantly, they neglect to explain the fact that security is only as strong as the weakest link.
Sure, if you find a random hash and the only information you have about it is the hash function and the fact that the input was 256 bits, then yes you have 2^256 possibilities. However, in reality that is rarely the case when the user is involved. If the 256bits are a 32 character/byte long password, then an assumption of 96 options per byte is not too unrealistic. It represents roughly all printable characters in 7 bit ASCII. This reduces the complexity by about 40 000 billion. So instead of a 4 billionth chance after 37 times the age of the universe, you have a roughly 400 000th chance after 126.8 years. It is of course, still a ridicules large amount of effort. If we throw in the ASICs, we can of course slice the number by 1000 and end up with 1/400th chance. Still an impractical amount of effort given galaxies of super computers.

Now lets assume that we know that this password is from someone a little bit more stupid and unaware. Lets say the password is only lower case a-z. This gives 26 options per byte and thus 26^32 options in total. This is still 256 bits into the hash function, but we know the complexity of the input is far lower. In fact, it reduces the complexity by about 6*10^31 or 60 000 billion billion billion. In other words, the giga galactic super computer has a roughly 1/900th chance of solving this every second. If we throw in ASICs, it should solve this every second even at worst case. Still ridiculously impractical, but also very far away from what this video describes. However, if we start stripping out more complexity, say reducing the input down to 12 characters, each with 26 options, we are left with a complexity of 26^12, roughly 95 million billion or something a single computer with ASICs could solve within 47 days at worst. Still 256 bit security, but knowing the true complexity means it's solvable.

I once saw an argument based on energy rather than speed that followed this very general outline:


Suppose you had a computer that operated at absolute maximum theoretical efficiency, so that there was no way it could possibly use less energy to flip a bit from zero to one, or one to zero. Suppose that's all this computer did: flip a single bit from one to zero and back again, over and over. (No counting: that's too complicated, reserved for a future version of the system. Certainly no complicated hashing or other common brute-force crypto-attack techniques: this is just a prototype.) Suppose you put this computer in the most naturally-cold place in the universe, to maximize its efficiency. (Don't want to spend energy on cooling, only on bit-flipping.)


Now suppose you could capture the entire energy output of a standard-size supernova, and feed this energy into your super-cold bit-flipper--assuming the existence of whatever energy-storage technology would be necessary to spread out the energy consumption over whatever time interval the bit-flipper required.


A supernova's worth of energy would be enough to power the bit-flipper through about 2^192 bit flips; which means you'd need to feed in 2^64 supernovas to get all the way up to 2^256. So that's version 0.1. By version 1.0, you'd need an actual crypto-attack algorithm, rather than just bit flipping, where each of the 2^256 attempts would require hundreds of thousands or maybe millions of bit flips. But..first things first.


So I probably have the numbers wrong, and perhaps some of the details as well...but that was the overall shape of the argument. I'd love to see you do a video on the real argument with actual numbers.

All cryptographic hash functions can be at least halved in strength using rainbow tables, meaning SHA256 is at most just 128-bit strong. Additionally, there are clever attacks that can partially reverse some of the hash primitive operations, which in the case of SHA256 reduce the true strength to ~ 2^64 bits.

A much simpler way to show it's impossible to brute force 2^256 number of combination is by energy argument. Landauer limit implied by the laws of physics sets a lower limit on the energy required to perform a computation. No computing device can use less energy even in principle. The amount of energy required to brute force 2^256 is greater than the energy our Sun will produce in 8 billion years of its life. The energy needed is even more than that produced in a supernova explosion. In other words, if you can collect all the energy produced when a giant star explodes in a supernova, and use that energy to power the most efficient computer possible in theory, that's still not enough energy to count 2^256 possible combination.

By the way, for practical purposes, even 128 bits is pretty safe. Even for 128 bits the amount of energy required would be extremely high (something like total energy produced in all of the US in a year if you include the fact that the actual computers aren't as efficient as set by theory and doing the actual encryption/hashing takes a lot more energy than just counting 2^128). That means even if brute-forcing 128 bits isn't as insanely impossible as 256 bits, for practical purposes, it's pretty safe, even from US govt.

I enjoy expressing this in terms of the absolute theoretical minimum amount of power it would take to run. To "forget" one bit, a computing device has to dissipate Boltzmann's Constant (about 2^-76) * the absolute temperature joules of energy. At liquid helium temperatures (4 degrees), that's 2*10-74 Joules. To check a single hash, the device would have to forget 256 bits. So to brute-force a 256 bit key, we are looking at 2 ^ (256 + 8 - 74), 2^190 Joules. Oh - divided by 2 to get an average. About 10^57, aka 1000^19.

The Sun releases about 3.846×10^26 Watts, so we are talking about 10^31 seconds on average. The universe is about 10^18 seconds old. So if we could harness the entire output of the sun to power a computational device running at liquid helium temperatures, we'd expect it to take around 10 trillion times the age of the universe (probably) to crack a single SHA hash.

I see many people posting things like, "But I use 2048 bit encryption, not 256 bit!"

While this is partially true, there are some misconceptions floating around about how this stuff actually works, say in a web server context. I'm not an expert, but I do know a bit about this particular space as I've been in the crypto world as an amateur for a long time now.

When someone says, "I use 2048 bit encryption," they likely mean they use a 2048-bit RSA certificate, most likely on their web server, email server, etc. This key is only used in the initial stages, and later a much smaller key, say 256 bits, is used. Also, during the stage where one must trust the certificate, a much smaller cryptographic hash function, say 256 bits again, is used.

Certificate authorities issue signed public keys (a certificate) which says, "if your browser trusts me, you can trust this other certificate I signed, because Math." In this case, that math is a secure hash (256 bits) signed with a very long RSA key (say, 4096 bits.) The weakest appears to be the 256-bit hash here, and it might be, but also consider that a RSA-key of length 2048 is considered to be the same as a symmetric cryptographic key of only 80 to 112 bits in length of AES. It's possible the hash function here is more secure than the system used to sign it.

Once your web browser trusts the certificate, it will then negotiate a symmetric key, which is once again most likely a 128 bit or 256 bit key. This is a unique (hopefully) key that only you and the web server knows, and both sides forget it once the data has been exchanged. This session key is used because public key cryptography is not fast enough to use directly, and may even be weaker. You'd also have to encrypt far more data if you used only RSA, and you would also have to convince the web server to trust you, as both sides would need a public key since they can only be used to encrypt in one direction.

and... if something is hashed, you don't guess the hash.  you guess the input to the hash, and hash that to verify your guess.  if you think you are looking at a word in the dictionary, then there are only about 100k words in the dictionary.  so it's the entropy of the input that's the problem, not the number of bits in the hash output.  (entropy is basically log2 of the number of guesses for the hash input, which is going to come from a finite list of items).  the only way you really have 256 bits of entropy going into the input of the hash is when the hash includes a 256 bit key in it as well (which meets the definition of a Message Authentication Code - a hash that includes a password/key mashed in with the data being hashed).

the reality of it is that you will have this super-string cipher, then there is always something dumb done with the key itself, or the ciphertext. it is common for an encrypted file to be sitting on the filesystem, but the filename describes what's in the file. or they key is encrypted on the filesystem, which is encrypted by a chain of encrypted keys with the key at the top of it; which turns breaking it into a one-time development effort. then people upload ciphertexts into the cloud, giving their key to the cloud in the process, or having an indexed representation of the plaintext sitting on the same machine as the ciphertext.

the strong security of aes is basically only really preserved when an encrypted blob is end-to-end encrypted with a trusted app on a trusted operating system. governments don't break crypto. they install trojans into operating systems if one of the previous dumb problems didn't already leak the info.

Here is an argument that even 128-bits is well beyond what any organization, including large state funded organizations can defeat.
Instead of talking about how large a computer is, or how long the computation takes, lets look at how much electrical power the computer will need.
Suppose you design a very efficient circuit which can run one billion operations per second while drawing a single milliwatt of power. Rounding up that is 2^30 operations per second per milliwatt.
For a kilowatt you get one million times more, rounding up that is 2^^50 operations per second per kilowatt.
In one hour there are 3,600 seconds, lets round that up to 4,096 = 2^12 seconds. So our theoretical device could perform 2^62 operations per killowatt hour.
To perform 2^128 operations we will therefore need 2^66 killowatt hours (kWh) of power.
Suppose we get electrical power very cheaply (bulk discount, we are going to need absurd amounts of power). Say 1/256 of a USD per kWh. So the 2^128 operations will require 2^58 USD worth of electrical power.
That is, 2^18 trillion USD = 262,144 trillion USD.
That is 14,000 times the estimated GDP of the USA in 2016.

0:27 "You have no better method than to just guess and check random messages". Eeerr.. no, just no. You wrongly assume, both here and in the rest of the video, that the only (or best) method to crack 128/256 bit cryptography is a brute force attack. On the contrary, beyond a certain number of bits it is ridiculous to even think of attempting a brute force attack, for exactly the reasons you explained in the video. Instead you try various side-channel attacks (timing attacks, covert channel attacks, differential fault attacks, maintenance hooks, known/chosen plaintext attacks, power-monitoring attacks, acoustic cryptanalysis attacks etc)

Furthermore, even brute force attacks can be greatly sped up via using dictionaries and leaked password lists (which can be *huge*), along with cryptanalysis of the most common used passwords. Oh, and the implementation or mode of the cryptography also matters a lot. For example the GCM (Galois/Counter Mode) mode of AES is much more secure than the CBC (Cipher Block Chaining) mode, with AES-128-GCM even considered more secure than AES-256-CBC. That despite GCM being much more efficient and faster with multi-core processors.

This video is pretty misleading.  It's a good illustration of how big a 256 bit number is, but NOT a good illustration of how secure 256 bit security is.  These cryptographic hash functions are broken and need to be replaced every few years.  This happens because weaknesses are found in the algorithm that make them easier to guess, and has very little to do with raw computing power.  SHA-1 is now considered dangerously weak, and output 160 bits.  No one made a computer that checked all 2^160 combinations.  People found weaknesses in the algorithm.  This has been true for almost everything in cryptography from the Enigma to MD5.

But hypothetically, you don't need anywhere near that amount of computation to break a hash function. The function is well known and has 64 "rounds" of calculations. This means someone who has the time can "unravel" the loop to create a single in-line function for each bit to the task (given a specific block to work with)....and reduce the complexity with simple rules (such as 0 AND X is 0, 1 OR X is 1, etc.). Given that a very small part of that block is a "niche" value that can change, you only need to reverse the in-line function based on those bits to figure out the digest required.....and then you get the niche possibilities.

I wanted to see how this number compares to a googol, so:

2^256 = 2^(10*25.6) = (2^10)^25.6 ~ (10^3)^25.6 ~ 10^77.

So to get to a googol you would have to get to 2^256 10 thousand billion billion times. Huh.

OK let's take all that stupid 'guesswork' out of it. What we are talking about is a "Dual Prime Composite " In other words the unique area of a specific rectangle, with sides of prime integer length. A trivial example:- 10,057. Now let's pretend we are blithering idiots and start guessing... It is known as "The Sieve of Eratosthenes" Prime Composite Factorisation. Does 10,057 divide by 3?...No, ...by 5, NO! , by 7 ?...No... by 11, 13, 17,19, 23, 29,...NO! NO! NO!.... by 31, 37, 41, 43, 47?....NO! NO! NO!.... So instead we use MATHEMATICS.... Duh...!!!!.... Why is Mathematics better than guesswork? .... Here is why. 10,057 is a little less than the square of 101. and 101 x 101 = 10,201. and 10,201 - 10,057 leaves a remainder of 144. which is the square of 12.  So we now know that 10,057 is (101 +12) x (101 - 12) = 113 x 89 our two Prime numbers. (As with most 'Trivial' examples, problems worthy of attack, show their mettle by fighting back.) An Arbitrary Precision Calculator, should with appropriate programming, be able to Factor a 256 Bit Dual Prime Composite into it's two 128 Bit Primes, in a matter of seconds. or minutes if using a very old computer. AS FOR SECURITY...????.... CRACKED STINKING STALE EGGS IN A THIN DAMP BROWN PAPER BAG IS A LOT MORE SECURE THAN 256 Bit Security. ....BECAUSE OF "MATHEMATICS". ...like Grade School Algebra.
